column1: 1179252;"SACRED HEART OF JESUS";"110 HUMBOLT AVE";"WADSWORTH";"OH";44281;"MEDINA";3303346272;"http://www.shswadsworth.org/";"sah_badams@tccsa.net";"A hearty welcome from Sacred Heart of Jesus School is extended to all who desire to learn more about the beauty within. This 2018-2019 school year promises to be loaded with many spiritually satisfying and educationally fulfilling opportunities. These experiences will encompass our school theme of “Jesus Show Me How To Be…
column2: and help us grow closer to Him through our actions
column3: our service to others
column4: our positive relationships
column5: and our efforts to spread His word. The theme will also grow as each month a new word of action will be the center of our school’s efforts. Spreading kindness is a great way to begin a new season as we concentrate on good deeds and healthy relationships. With this in mind
column6: I would like to welcome all new families to the Family of the “Heart” and I pray that you experience a wonderful transition to our school. God has blessed us with teachers who challenge students to move beyond their own expectations reaching for more knowledge and applying it to solve problems and think critically. Our thirst to learn will be quenched in the classroom as well as through the many out-of-class experiences including field trips and after school activities.

column1: The unwavering support of our current families and the environment they have helped to create have distinguished Sacred Heart from being an ordinary school.  We are far from average in all aspects of our makeup. A spirit of enthusiasm and excitement along with a vibrant atmosphere envelops SHS. We realize that when you entrust your children to us a safe environment filled with spiritual and educational nourishment is expected.   Sacred Heart is committed to deliver with a fervor that should please all.
As we reflect on 2017-18
column2: it is quite obvious our students enjoyed many successes including our 1st trip to the nationals
column3: in Chicago
column4: with our Quiz Bowl Team. As usual
column5: our Science Fair projects were showered with accolades from the state of Ohio including various monetary awards and scholarships. The 32 strong
column6: that comprised our 8th grade class will be missed. They provided leadership and set examples for all to emulate. However
column7: we are fortunate to have many other students ready and eager to continue their efforts. Artistically
column8: through music
column10: we excelled. Athletically
column11: our students garnered championships and earned 1st place honors. Academically
column12: we strived to be the best with many accepting high school scholarships and commendations. Most importantly
column19: we walked with Jesus more closely.

column1: Our staff will travel beyond limits
column2: to make sure all are welcome
column3: all are respected and all are treated with dignity and compassion. We have a passion to teach
column4: to nurture and to share our blessings with all who enter through our doors. Sacred Heart pledges to: Embrace and teach the Catholic Faith; Welcome all who desire to learn; Provide excellent academics and rich spiritual opportunities; and Live our love for God and others through service. Together let’s dive into the waters of the 2018-19 school year splashing each other
column5: loving each other and caring about each other . We plan to have fun with friends and family surrounded by the Holy Spirit.  It doesn’t get any better than that! 1179257;"SAINT JOHN SCHOOL";"7911 DEPOT RD";"ASHTABULA";"OH";44004;"ASHTABULA";4409975531;"http://www.sjheralds.org/";"maureen.burke@neomin.org";"Catholic Education has been a vital presence in Ashtabula for 150 years.
The oldest of the parishes in Ashtabula
column2: Saint Joseph Parish
column3: opened an elementary school in September 1865 when the Reverend John Tracey was pastor. The building that is currently recognized as the school building was built in 1877. In the early years of the school
column4: the Sisters of Saint Joseph and the Sisters of Charity from Cincinnati were engaged as teachers for the school. In 1897
column5: the Holy Humility of Mary Sisters (the “Blue Nuns”) took charge of the educational program in the school.

column2: the growing population in the Ashtabula Harbor area led to the establishment of Mother of Sorrows Parish and the opening of Mother of Sorrows School. The founding principal was Miss Mary Cox. By 1892
column3: the Sisters of Saint Joseph from West Baden
column4: Pennsylvania were in charge of the educational operation of the school. In future years
column5: the Sisters of the Benedictine order from Erie
column7: the Sisters of Charity of Saint Augustine
column8: the Sisters of Notre Dame and the Holy Humility of Mary Sisters staffed the school as teachers and administrators.

column1: In September of 1954
column2: Our Lady of Mount Carmel was opened under the leadership of Father Joseph A. Feicht..

column1: Responding to the needs of the Ashtabula area
column2: the Diocese of Youngstown recognized the need for a Catholic high school in the Ashtabula area in the early 1950’s. The Saint John school building was purchased on the June 24
column4: the feast day of Saint John the Baptist
column5: for whom the school is named. The building was formerly the Station Avenue School and housed elementary classes from 1890-1952. In September 1953
column6: Saint John High School opened. On November 5
column8: the school building was destroyed by fire
column9: delaying the formal dedication. While the building was rebuilt
column10: classes were held in Saint Joseph School and the Pacific School annex. The formal dedication of the school was held on November 14
column12: the building was ready to re-open and all of the students were back under one roof. In 1963
column13: growing enrollment led to the need for building on an addition.

column1: The Reverend Joseph Feicht was the founding pastor and Sister Visitation (Elizabeth Staudt) H.H.M. was the first principal. The Sisters of the Holy Humility of Mary played a vital role in the academic and religious development of the school. Diocesan priests provided leadership and direction through a variety of academic and spiritual roles. Father John Hoey
column2: Father Robert Flynn
column3: Father Frederick Slavin
column4: and Father Paul Tobin have had official positions
column5: while priests serving the local parishes have also provided pastoral services to the students.

column2: the three area Catholic elementary schools
column3: Saint Joseph
column4: Mother of Sorrows and Mount Carmel underwent a consolidation plan and became the Ashtabula Catholic Elementary School (ACES) and were housed at Mother of Sorrows Parish and Mount Carmel Parish (for a short time the 7th and 8th grade of the consolidated school was housed at the St. John’s high school building).

column2: due to declining enrollment and accompanying financial problems
column3: the Youngstown Diocese made the decision to close Saint John High School. Notwithstanding that decision
column4: a committed and enthusiastic group of parents
column5: teachers and community supporters banded together to re-open Saint John as an independent Catholic High School. After raising significant money to retire the school debt
column6: this group sought to purchase Saint John from the diocese. The diocese agreed to sell the building and its contents to Saint John supporters for $100. In September of 1992
column7: Saint John High School re-opened as an Independent Catholic High School under the governance of a Board of Directors.

column2: reorganization again took place. There was a consolidation of all of the Catholic schools in the Ashtabula area and Saint John Catholic School was born under the governance of the Youngstown Diocese. This was a K-12 school with two campuses: a K-6 campus at the Mount Carmel Parish on Columbus Ave. and a 7-12 campus at the Saint John Building on Station Ave.

column1: In 2012 the Board was approached by a group of alumni and community members to purchase the Saybrook public school on Depot Road in Saybrook Township. The school would be able to house the enitre PreK-12 student body. The Board approached the Diocese about the possibility and in August 2012 the school opened the doors at the new location.
The new location underwent a major transformation with more than 200 volunteers assisting in the project. The school now has a new cafeteria and kitchen
column2: new science labs
column3: and many other state of the art facilities.

column1: Throughout the years
column2: the school has retained its commitment to fostering scholarship
column3: faith and leadership. The family spirit
column4: the importance of tradition
column5: and the commitment to the young people of the area have allowed for the preservation of Catholic education in Ashtabula. It is a proud history and we embrace it as our legacy for the future.";"http://www.sjheralds.org/Default.aspx";"https://www.facebook.com/StJohnAshtabula/";"http://www.sjheralds.org/Employment.aspx";"http://www.sjheralds.org/EnrollmentForms.aspx";"http://www.sjheralds.org/Parent-StudentHandbook.aspx";;;;"x";"x";;"http://www.sjheralds.org/sysimages/logo.png";"7:30 am – 2:20 pm";"7:30 am – 2:20 pm";"7:30 am – 2:20 pm";"7:30 am – 2:20 pm";"7:30 am – 2:20 pm";"Closed";"Closed";

1179280;"SCIOTO RIDGE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL";"8715 BIG BEAR AVE";"POWELL";"OH";43065;"DELAWARE";7406574800;"https://www.olentangy.k12.oh.us";"melany_ondrus@olsd.us";"Scioto Ridge Elementary School has been recognized by the state for its committment to serving students and families connected to the military. The school received a Purple Star Award from the Ohio Department of Education in May.
Scioto Ridge Elementary joins Liberty Middle School
column2: Olentangy Hyatts Middle School
column3: Olentangy Shanahan Middle School
column4: Olentangy High School and Orange High School in earning the award
column5: which was created this year.

column1: The Ohio Department of Education's Purple Star Award recognizes schools that show a major commitment to serving students and families connected to our nation’s armed forces. Purple Star awardees receive a special Purple Star recognition to display in their buildings. The Purple Star Advisory Board
column2: formed by the Ohio departments of Education
column3: Higher Education
column4: Veterans Services and Adjutant General
column5: helps decide eligibility.

column1: A Purple Star school will receive the designation for two years. After two years
column2: the school must reapply. The Purple Star emblem was selected because purple symbolizes support for military families.

column1: There are 34
column2: 000 children in Ohio with one or more parents serving in the military. This includes the children of active duty
column3: reserve and Ohio National Guard members. Some of these children will attend six to nine different schools throughout their K-12 educational experiences. In addition to changing schools often
column4: a student also can be affected by a parent’s deployment. Schools can help students and families face these issues by connecting them with the resources they need.

column1: “A supportive school environment can have a significant impact on our military-connected students
column2: ” said State Superintendent Paolo DeMaria. “These Purple Star schools provide our children and families with the resources they need to be successful. We’re thankful for their service and honored to continue the important work of improving services for Ohio’s military families.”";"https://www.olentangy.k12.oh.us/Scioto%20Ridge";"https://www.facebook.com/pages/Scioto-Ridge-Elementary-School/1508533442767226";"https://www.olentangy.k12.oh.us/domain/58";"https://www.olentangy.k12.oh.us/Page/962";"https://www.olentangy.k12.oh.us/cms/lib/OH01914664/Centricity/shared/elementary%20files/Official%202018-19%20ES%20Handbook%206-11-18.pdf";;;"x";"x";;;;"8:50 a.m - 3:40 p.m";"8:50 a.m - 3:40 p.m";"8:50 a.m - 3:40 p.m";"8:50 a.m - 3:40 p.m";"8:50 a.m - 3:40 p.m";"Closed";"Closed";

column1: 1179281;"SCIOTOVILLE ELEMENTARY ACADEMY";"5540 3RD ST";"SCIOTOVILLE";"OH";45662;"Scioto";7407762920;"http://www.sea.k12.oh.us";"rick.bowman@tartan.k12.oh.us";"At SEA
column2: we strive to educate every student well. We believe that the best way to do that is for schools to partner with parents and the community to help educate children.

column1: Parents are a critical factor in children’s educational success because they are a child’s first and best teachers. Research has shown that children whose parents are involved in their education perform at higher levels than those whose parents are not involved.
So we encourage parents to get involved in a variety of ways. Parents can make sure children understand the importance of education
column2: and they can help children learn outside of school. Below are some tips for helping your elementary student learn at home as well as in school.

column1: The first one is the most important: Read. Read to your child. Read with your child. Let your child see you reading every day
column2: so that he or she understands the importance of learning to read well.

column1: Read to and with your child
column2: and have your child read to you.

column1: Encourage your child to keep a journal of daily events.
Keep books available to your child
column2: and make regular trips to the public library.

column1: When you shop for groceries
column2: have your child help you find items and then estimate the cost of the purchase.

column1: Discuss different kinds of jobs and careers in your community to help your child understand that school prepares them for a career.
Visit museums
column2: zoos and city art exhibits with your child.

column1: Help your child identify and set fitness goals. Make walking
column2: hiking or biking a family activity.

column1: Talk to your child about the importance of education.
Meet with your child’s teachers regularly to monitor progress.
Compliment your child’s work and success in school.
Make sure your child does each day’s homework assignment. Set aside a quiet place for homework and set a regular time each day for it.
Listen to music together
column2: and have art materials (crayons
column3: paint
column4: brushes
column5: pencils

1179302;"SHAWNEE ELEMENTARY";"712 CLEVELAND RD E";"HURON";"OH";44839;"ERIE";4194331234;"http://www.huronhs.com/";"kberry@huronhs.com";"Huron City Schools has a proud legacy of tradition and spirit of excellence. The district serves approximately 1
column2: 450 students yearly
column3: and is comprised of four facilities
column4: including one high school
column5: one junior high school (serving grades 7-8)
column7: and one primary school (serving grades pre-k-2).

column1: The school district has excelled because of the unique combination of home
column2: schools and community working collaboratively for all students within the city. Huron educators believe that in order to be competitive in the new century
column3: schools must embrace change and create a high performing learning environment for students and teachers.

column1: To meet the needs of the 21st century learner Huron City Schools curriculum is aligned with new State standards designed to challenge students pre-k through graduation. Instructional delivery is enhanced by hands on field experiences
column2: digital and blended learning experiences
column3: college partnerships through Dual Enrollment opportunities and Post Secondary Enrollment Options (PSEOP)
column4: Advanced Placement course work and partnerships with local agencies. Huron teachers
column5: administrators and support staff participate in frequent intensive professional development activities designed to improve instructional strategies and instructional content.

column1: Huron City Schools understands and embraces the role of technology in the education of children. Today’s learners enter school already immersed in a technologically driven society. Huron teachers utilize SMART board or TAP-it technology to enhance instruction by maximizing learning opportunities through digital experiences. All students have access to an array of mobile devices including carts of iPads
column2: Chromebooks
column3: and laptops while each building maintains traditional computer labs. The district is aggressively increasing the number and variety of mobile devices available at all grade levels. Huron will continue to invest heavily in infrastructure upgrades to allow for instant and seamless connectivity for all students.

column1: Huron City Schools recognizes the importance of extra curricular opportunities to supplement a rewarding pre-k through graduation educational experience for students. Elementary school offerings in choir
column2: band
column3: general music and art serve as the springboard for a life long appreciation of fine arts for many children. The Huron band routinely earns high marks for their performance at various regional and state competitions.

column1: Clubs
column2: student organizations and community service activities are an important part of a holistic student experience. Huron offers many opportunities that engage students in the act of volunteerism. Students involved in Teen Leadership Corps and Student Council provide hands-on service and support throughout the year within the community. Developing a passion for civic responsibility in young people is something Huron City Schools takes seriously and is committed to achieving.

column1: An athletic tradition beginning with a multitude of organized biddy programs has evolved over the years due to the accomplishments of many individuals and teams. Volunteers throughout the community continue to support Huron student athletes with their time and financial contributions. Huron City Schools is known for their acclaimed facilities that include the first local football stadium with artificial turf
column2: a renovated soccer field
column3: and a new baseball and softball complex. 1179320;"SIMON KENTON SCHOOL";"705 N IDA ST";"KENTON";"OH";43326;"HARDIN";4196744158;"https://www.hardindd.org/";"klbrown@hardindd.org";"The Hardin County Early Intervention Program focuses on parent involvement with their children’s learning and development.  Families receive a guide to the evaluation process during the first home visit.  Children receive a complete evaluation upon referral for services including: vision
column2: hearing
column3: nutrition and social-emotional screenings
column4: developmental evaluation
column5: parent interview
column6: parent/child interaction observation and hands on evaluation from a therapist.  The team which includes parents
column8: Developmental Specialists and therapists determines eligibility for Early Intervention services.  Eligible children and families receive an IFSP to determine strengths
column10: outcomes and individual services.  Per Early Intervention Rule the Bayley III assessment is used to determine eligibility for the program.  The Assessment
column12: and Programming System for Infants and Young Children (AEPS) is used as a curriculum and ongoing assessment tool.  The Early Intervention staff strives to provide all services in the child’s natural environment by making home visits and encouraging parent involvement and participation in therapy sessions.  Parents are given developmental questionnaires to help them monitor their child’s development.  The final duty of the Early Intervention team is to help the child and family transition to preschool.  Parents are given information to make decisions concerning the best preschool program for their child.  We introduce parents to the preschool team in their school district and participate in all meetings and evaluations to make a smooth transition to preschool services.

column1: Simon Kenton School continues to be an active part of the Help Me Grow system in Hardin County
column2: which is funded in part by the Ohio Department of Developmental Disabilities.  This grant is designated to improve the collaboration of agencies serving children under the age of three (3) and their families under the direction of the Hardin County Family and Children First Council.  Referrals are sent to central intake 1-800-755-4769.  Simon Kenton School is contracts with the Family and Children First Council to provide Early Intervention Service Coordination and evaluations.  A full time Service Coordinator provides dedicated service coordination for families.  Families and children receive services according to each individualized family service plan including; special instruction
column3: speech/language therapy
column4: physical therapy
column5: and occupational therapy.  Services are provided year round.";"https://www.hardindd.org/simonkenton";"https://www.facebook.com/pages/Simon-Kenton-School/111099902286064";"https://www.hardindd.org/form__map";"https://www.hardindd.org/form__map";;;;"x";;;;"https://static.wixstatic.com/media/05f899_fedb4b91772241b69c91f40860a77d56~mv2_d_2400_3000_s_4_2.jpg/v1/fill/w_149

column2: we take pride in providing a safe
column3: positive and welcoming environment where all children have the opportunity to succeed.   We have a dedicated staff that puts the needs of students at the forefront of all they do.

column1: Our students have the opportunity to participate in a variety of activities and programs including; Accelerated Reader
column2: student council
column3: band
column4: “Takin it to the Schools”
column5: Big Brothers/Big Sisters
column8: Young Authors
column9: and the County Math Tournament.  Students can also take advantage of our walking club and basketball club which are held before school.    During the 2017/2018 school year
column10: we added a morning reading program for third grade students and we also expanded our after school intervention sessions to include enrichment opportunities.   These are just a few of the experiences that are available to our students at South.

column1: It is a priority at South for students to learn the value of “giving back.” Our students participated in many service projects such as Relay for Life
column2: Coats for kids
column3: and Rainbow Connection’s coin challenge.   Our student council also sponsored several activities throughout the year including Spirit Days to raise money for a variety of charities.

column1: Our “Recess Rally” was a HUGE success again this past year.  Our students
column2: families and sponsors raised over $12
column3: 000 to make needed improvements.    We appreciate all of the families and community members that have continued to support this event.  Watch for the new additions and more improvements coming soon.

column1: South School houses over 400 students in grades preschool through fifth grade. Our preschool program earned a 5 star rating
column2: the highest possible
column3: from The Ohio Department of Education for the second year in a row for providing a quality program for children ages 3-5.

column1: In addition to the opportunities provided by our teachers and staff; our South School PTG provided many fun and educational activities such as assemblies
column2: field trips
column3: and Santa Shop just to name a few.   Thank you to our PTG for all they do. column1: 1179347;"SOUTH ELEMENTARY SCHOOL";"3555 STATE ROUTE 792";"STOCKPORT";"OH";43787;"MORGAN";7405592377;"http://www.mlsd.k12.oh.us/";;"Morgan South Elementary was one of three brand new elementary buildings to open in Morgan County in the fall of 2002.  Since that time
column2: we have made it our goal to show our appreciation to our county for helping to support our efforts for new buildings
column3: by providing the best instruction possible for all students.  Our mission is to provide an education of the highest quality that drives all of our students to excel while meeting their individual needs
column4: developing their character and potential as we prepare them for the future.

column1: Our school lies in the center of three local villages
column2: and we are proud to have strong ties to these communities.  Because of these ties
column3: we are able to offer a number of character building and incentive programs for our students.  We believe that building character
column4: compassion
column5: and leadership skills is of the utmost importance.  One way we try to encourage these skills is through our Change of Heart program.  Students taking part in this program learn how to lead by example
column6: and have a strong impact on the atmosphere of our school.  Another way we encourage students to do well is through our Homework Heroes program.  This is an incentive program that rewards students who consistently complete and turn in their homework.   Without the support of our community and the local businesses
column7: programs such as these would not be possible.

column1: Our staff believes that in order for children to be successful
column2: schools and families must work together.  For this reason
column3: we encourage parent volunteers
column4: and try to organize several family events each year
column5: such as our Fall Festival
column8: and Awards Ceremonies each nine weeks.  Our goal is for students to feel confident and at home in their school.  For this reason
column9: we chose the vision statement:  Strong Optimism Unites This Home.

column1: South Elementary has been recognized by the Ohio Department of Education as a High Progress School of Honor based on the 2013-2014 Ohio School Report Card on student reading and math performance.  South has also earned the title of 2014 SOAR Award for High Progress (grades 4-8).  South earned this award based on the 2014 annual school composite index.";"http://www.mlsd.k12.oh.us/elementary/south";"https://www.facebook.com/pg/MorganLocalSchoolDistrict/";"http://www.mlsd.k12.oh.us/district/job-opportunities";"http://www.mlsd.k12.oh.us/studentsparents/kindergarten-registration";"http://www.mlsd.k12.oh.us/component/docman/cat_view/466-handbook?Itemid=507";;;;"x";;;"http://www.mlsd.k12.oh.us/images/morganweblogo2.jpg";"9:00 a.m  3:30 p.m";"9:00 a.m  3:30 p.m";"9:00 a.m  3:30 p.m";"9:00 a.m  3:30 p.m";"9:00 a.m  3:30 p.m";"Closed";"Closed";

column1: 1179359;"SOUTHERN LOCAL SCHOOL";"38095E STATE ROUTE 39";"SALINEVILLE";"OH";43945;"COLUMBIANA";7402833347;"http://www.southern.k12.oh.us/";;"Southern Local School District has undergone significant changes since 1990 building assessment. In 1990 the District operated five schools. Number Sixteen Elementary School was a 8
column2: 998 s.f. 1938 building which they used for grades K-4. Franklin Elementary School was a 7
column3: 500 s.f. 1923/1938/1950 building which they used for grades K-4. Highlandtown Elementary School was a 7
column4: 980 s.f. 1940 building which they used for grades 1-4. Southern Middle School was a 31
column5: 917 s.f. 1938 building which they used for grades 5-8. Southern Local High School was a 49
column6: 952 s.f. 1962 building which they used for grades 9-12.

column2: the District closed/sold Number Sixteen Elementary School and Franklin Elementary School. Highlandtown Elementary School had temporary modular classrooms placed on site
column3: was renamed Southern Primary School and used for grades K-2. Southern Middle School was renamed Southern Intermediate School and used for grades 3-6. Southern Local High School had temporary modular classrooms placed on-site and is now used for grades 7-12.

column1: In January of 2002 the Board of Education and Administrators braved the cold for a groundbreaking ceremony for the new K-12 complex. Construction for this new campus began in March of 2002.
December of 2002 saw students and staff of the Jr/Sr High packing and moving into the elementary wing so that construction renovation could be completed on the high school wing.

November of 2003 the Jr/Sr High students and staff began occupation of the current K-12 complex. By January of 2004 all students and staff claimed ownership of the new Southern Local K-12 complex.";"http://www.southern.k12.oh.us/";"https://web.facebook.com/pages/Southern-Local-Elementary-School/1554371868114900?_rdc=1&_rdr";"http://www.southern.k12.oh.us/?DivisionID=20939&ToggleSideNav=ShowAll";"http://www.sles.southern.k12.oh.us/?PageName=%27ParentInfo%27&Page=%27RegistrationDates%27";"http://www.southern.k12.oh.us/?DivisionID=21526&ToggleSideNav=ShowAll";;;"x";"x";;;;;;;;;;;

column2: Southington Middle School and Southington Elementary School. Chalker High School is named for Newton Chalker who was born in Southington and later became an attorney. Mr. Chalker built and donated the Chalker Building which sits at 4432 St. Rt. 305 in Southington. The original campus at 4432 St. Rt. 305 is where the Chalker Building
column3: 1907 Building and the sports complex currently sit.

column1: Southington Local Schools new K-12 campus was completed in 2011. The 43 acres of land where the new campus sits was generously donated by Mr. & Mrs. Donald Donaldson in 2007 and is next door to the Donaldson Rolling “D” Farms. Students first day at the new campus was Tuesday
column2: September 6
column3: 2011 and the first graduating class from the new campus graduated Sunday
column4: June 3

column2: Southington Schools average daily membership is approximately 600 students. Southington Local offers a variety of academics

column1: 1179363;"SPECTRUM RESOURCE CENTER AND SCHOOL";"300 BROADWAY";"LORAIN";"OH";44052;"LORAIN";4406544174;"https://spectrumlorain.com";"spectrum.christyreed@gmail.com";"Spectrum Resource Center & School is a day treatment program specifically designed to meet the needs of students in grades PK-12+ that as a result of their educational diagnosis have a difficult time meeting their full potential in the traditional school environment. Students considered appropriate for placement at Spectrum are those that require a multimodal approach to academics combined with an intensive behavior management system to function successfully across settings. To meet the demands of this special population
column2: Spectrum provides highly structured self contained units where students remain with their assigned teaching team to access direct instruction in all core subjects. This model establishes a daily routine with minimal distractions and transitions thereby increasing attentive skills and academic performance.

column1: Each classroom unit follows a specially designed curriculum map that aligns instruction with the common core state standards using state of the art methodologies and materials. A school wide positive behavior support system is a vital component of the Spectrum Program and has been designed to teach students coping strategies
column2: responsibility
column3: and resiliency to persevere. In the classroom
column4: staff collect data on individualized target behaviors and use both visual aids and behavioral cues to assist students in making progress towards goal attainment. In addition to the innovative academic and behavioral programming
column5: students receive social skills instruction based on research studies that indicates there is a high correlation between social skills development and the ability to succeed in school and beyond. By providing a structured framework for learning along with remedial and enriched academic curriculum
column6: Spectrum offers each student placed in our program an optimal opportunity to achieve their full potential.";"https://spectrumlorain.com";"https://web.facebook.com/spectrumlorain/?_rdc=1&_rdr";"https://spectrumlorain.com/careers/";"https://spectrumlorain.com/spectrum-resource-center-school/download-forms/";;;;;;;;"https://spectrumlorain.com/wp-content/themes/spectrum-lorain/img/logo.png";"7:30 am – 4:00 pm";"7:30 am – 4:00pm";"7:30 am – 4:00pm";"7:30 am – 4:00pm";"7:30 am – 4:00pm";"Closed";"Closed";

1179397;"ST BERNARD SCHOOL";"4615 TOWER AVE";"SAINT BERNARD";"OH";45217;"Hamilton";5136744200;"http://hs.sbepschools.org/";"rreynolds@sbepschools.org";"The St. Bernard-Elmwood Place Board of Education wants to take this opportunity to reaffirm its strong belief in the concept of local control over public education
column2: operating with statutory limitations.

column1: The Board of Education has the dual legal responsibilities of implementing statutory requirements for public education and fulfilling citizens’ desires for educating the community’s youth.
While the board has an obligation to assess citizens’ desires
column2: it is understood that when citizens elect delegates to represent them in the conduct of public education
column3: they endow their representatives with the authority to exercise their best judgment in making decisions that affect the school system.

column1: The board believes its primary purpose is to ensure the optimal learning experience for the children enrolled in its schools. We believe that we should constantly aim toward having the best school system possible within available resources. We have long realized that achieving district success is virtually impossible without citizens’ participation. For that reason
column2: we are convinced that the high level of success in the district is a reflection of the support we have received from the community.

column1: Pride and involvement have a way of perpetuating achievement. Let’s keep it going.";"http://hs.sbepschools.org/";"https://web.facebook.com/St-Bernard-Elementary-111108952895277/?_rdc=1&_rdr";"http://www.sbepschools.org/cms/One.aspx?portalId=2981761&pageId=3831523";"http://www.sbepschools.org/about_us/enrollment";"http://sbepschools.ss16.sharpschool.com/parents/school_forms_and_information";;;"x";;;;"https://scontent.flhe2-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-1/p320x320/20708194_111111082895064_3070101413673060309_n.jpg?_nc_cat=110&_nc_eui2=AeERyog2WCc2EWIVLa47uBOhzpL12lUmejeyCg18wye6fGsOq1FMog_3XDAeOy0SFdMT7sQJnep_d72w_Q3edl23xvCphznM9HfTnP7kGU3ouBKDQcZcMZlwbKj3PppFe5Q&_nc_ht=scontent.flhe2-1.fna&oh=39e6c16570d84688ee52655a81626611&oe=5C5F94D1";"7:50 a.m – 2:58 pm";"7:50 a.m – 2:58 pm";"7:50 a.m – 2:58 pm";"7:50 a.m – 2:58 pm";"7:50 a.m – 2:58 pm";"Closed";"Closed";

column1: St. Brendan Catholic Parish School was founded in 1964 and has been a strong presence in the community ever since. We offer 3- & 4-year-old preschool
column2: full-day kindergarten and first through eighth grades on our nine-acre campus.

column1: Best practices and integrated technology are used to connect learning with real-life application. Interactive lessons
column2: project-based learning
column3: STEM and authentic assessments enable students to be active participants in their education.

column1: Grades 1-4 each have their own iPad mini to use throughout the day and grades 5-8 are 1:1 each with their own chromebook. With guided instruction students experience the academic opportunities that accompany a technologically advanced school. Kindergarten utilize the iPad cart
column2: which they use both in the Technology Suite as well as in the classroom. Preschool through 8th grade classrooms have Interactive Projectors. Our technology makes learning come alive!

column1: We follow the State of Ohio standard curriculum infused with our Catholic Identity. In addition
column2: St. Brendan School has advanced programs: Spanish (Pre-8)
column3: algebra I
column4: advanced math and science
column5: as well as additional wellness and enrichment programs for all grade levels.

column1: The addition of a Curriculum Coordinator to our faculty has proved to be beneficial. Her role includes: researching classroom instruction that works
column2: investigating new technology that will enhance learning opportunities and teaching study and test-taking skills.

column1: Our dedicated faculty are licensed professionals that strive to cultivate the student's spiritual growth and academic achievement. Faculty and staff model our mission statement so that all may come to know Christ through us. We invite you to come visit St. Brendan School and experience for yourself
column2: our warm

column1: St. Cecilia School was the first Catholic School in the Columbus Diocese to receive OCSAA accreditation. We also received the Doyle Memorial Fund Award in the 2004-2005 school year. column1: 1179405;"ST CHRISTINE";"3125 S SCHENLEY AVE";"YOUNGSTOWN";"OH";44511;"MAHONING";3307924544;"https://www.stchristineschoolyoungstown.org/";"stchristineelem@youngstowndiocese.org";" Soon after the founding of the parish in 1953
column2: plans were underway for the building of  St. Christine Elementary School. Ground breaking for a combination temporary church and ten classroom school took place on Sunday afternoon
column3: March 28
column4: 1954. After hard work and the anxieties accompanying any building project
column5: the buildings plus a rectory and convent were blessed and dedicated on Sunday
column7: 1955. The school had opened in September 1955.

column1: Significant to the development of the parish school was the presence of the Daughters of Charity of St. Vincent dePaul
column2: from Emmitsburgh
column3: Maryland. They had been invited to the Diocese of Youngstown by Bishop Walsh to staff two parishes
column4: one of them being Saint Christine. In 1955
column5: four Daughters came to Youngstown and opened the school. They lived temporarily at St. Brendan Convent until the newly constructed convent was finished.

column1: The school enrollment grew rapidly from 350 pupils the first year in 1955
column2: to 650 pupils the following year. Accordingly the original 10 classrooms had to be expanded to 24 classrooms in 1957
column3: and to 32 classrooms in 1960
column4: when enrollment was nearly 1500 pupils.  Total cost of the school when it was completed was $845

column1: The Daughters of Charity provided a strong presence in the school and in the parish through those years. The highest number present at any one time was 17 when the school enrollment peaked at 1554 pupils in 1965. At that time there were 32 classrooms with half taught by a sister
column2: and the other half taught by lay persons. As enrollment began to decline and as there were fewer sisters
column3: competent and dedicated lay women especially took over the administration and teaching responsibilities in the school. In 1985 a pre-school was added. In 1988 the Daughters of Charity could no longer staff the parish school and left. Since then the Principal has been a lay woman and the total school staffed by competent lay persons.

column1: Over the years the school has reflected many changes and improvements in education and curriculum
column2: with the addition of a pre-school
column3: kindergarten
column4: music
column5: physical education
column6: computers and art. Over the years
column7: the school has often been recognized for its excellence and high academic achievement. Today it numbers close to 375 students
column8: Kindergarten through eighth grade";"https://www.stchristineschoolyoungstown.org/";"https://web.facebook.com/pg/St-Christine-School-419304811499805/";;"https://www.stchristineschoolyoungstown.org/72";"https://www.stchristineschoolyoungstown.org/media/1/St_%20Christine%20Student%20Parent%20Handbook%20%20%202017-18(1).pdf";;;"x";"x";"x";;"https://static.radiuswebtools.com/templates/stchristineschoolyoungstown-org_clear/images/logo.png";"7:50 - 2:20";"7:50 - 2:20";"7:50 - 2:20";"7:50 - 2:20";"7:50 - 2:20";"Closed";"Closed";

To accomplish the vision we continually strive to build a community of faith in which the Christian message

column1: We believe that Catholic faith formation and Catholic religious education are the purpose and focal point of our school. Faith values permeate all subject areas in the curriculum. We call our students to service not only to the Catholic community
column2: but to other segments of society as well. Our school policies
column3: programs
column4: and day-to-day interaction proclaim the Gospel of Jesus. Thus we teach the foundations of Catholic belief and foster the development of prayer life
column5: a sense of community

column1: We believe that we share the vision of Jesus within an atmosphere designed to celebrate and practice the love of God and neighbor. We motivate students to grow academically
column2: culturally
column3: and socially. Jesus remains with the community He formed
column4: and we are privileged to witness and share that Presence.";"https://www.stcolumbkilleschool.org/";"https://web.facebook.com/pg/stcolumbkilleschoolfamily/";;"https://www.stcolumbkilleschool.org/registrationforms";"https://stcolumbkilleschool.org/documents/2017/8/FAMILY%20HANDBOOK%202017-18.pdf";;;;"x";"x";;"https://www.stcolumbkilleschool.org/pictures/2015/6/St.%20Columbille%20Logo%20smaller.jpg";"7:55 - 2:45";"7:55 - 2:45";"7:55 - 2:45";"7:55 - 2:45";"7:55 - 2:45";"Closed";"Closed";

column1: 1179410;"ST DOMINIC";"371 PEDRETTI AVE";"CINCINNATI";"OH";45238;"HAMILTON";5132511276;"https://www.stdominic-k-8.org/";"saintdominic@stdominicdelhi.org";"Welcome to St. Dominic School!  We are located in Delhi Township
column2: 6 miles west of downtown Cincinnati.  The school
column3: operated by St. Dominic Parish
column4: is an Archdiocesan Roman Catholic elementary serving students in Pre-K through eighth grade.

column1: St. Dominic School
column2: “A Place to Grow”
column3: proudly exists to serve the individual needs
column4: both spiritual and educational
column5: of the children of the parish and local community.

column1: Our school strives to guide each student into becoming a faith-filled child of God through a strong religion program
column2: numerous liturgical functions
column3: active student ministries in the church and school
column4: an emphasis on Catholic services and celebrations
column5: an immersion in a character education program
column6: and an active student-led Christian Service program.  Closely related to the spiritual development of each student is a strong academic program which utilizes differentiation as the groundwork to assist each child in recognizing his or her own potential.

column1: We are blessed with warm and caring staff members who are constantly searching for ways to grow professionally and spiritually.  Every year staff members apply for and received instructional grants to enhance their curriculum.  One of our teachers has attained National Board Certified Teacher while several others have received the NCEA Teacher of the Year Award for Region Six (Michigan and Ohio).  All faculty members serve on one of three school committees which work to continually improve every facet of the school.
Knowing that the most important teachers for our students are their own parents
column2: St. Dominic School strives to ensure parent support and involvement in many areas.  Each day parents volunteer in the building
column3: work on PTO projects
column4: or serve on the Education Commission.  The St. Dominic PTO has received the prestigious NCEA Home/School Award.

column1: St. Dominic School has had the pleasure of witnessing the growth of many generations of students who are now doctors
column2: engineers
column3: attorneys
column4: accountants
column5: politicians
column7: and service persons.  Many of the graduates are faith-filled parents
column8: grandparents
column9: and great grandparents within the St. Dominic Parish community.  Since St. Dominic Parish opened its doors over seventy-five years ago
column10: it is easy to see why St. Dominic School has become a place for children to grow.";"https://www.stdominic-k-8.org/";"https://web.facebook.com/stdominicdelhi/?_rdc=1&_rdr";;"https://www.stdominic-k-8.org/Portals/3/Files/Home/Preschool/Preschool%20Student%20Registration%20Form.pdf";"https://www.stdominic-k-8.org/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=g8pNjtzBSCs%3d&tabid=307&portalid=3";;;"x";"x";"x";;"https://www.stdominic-k-8.org/Portals/3/StDominicSchoolLogo185.png";"8:00 a.m.-3:00 p.m";"8:00 a.m.-3:00 p.m";"8:00 a.m.-3:00 p.m";"8:00 a.m.-3:00 p.m";"8:00 a.m.-3:00 p.m";"Closed";"Closed";

column1: 1179411;"ST EDWARD";"433 COTTAGE ST";"ASHLAND";"OH";44805;"ASHLAND";4192897456;"https://www.stedwardashland.org/";"school@stedwardashland.org";"St. Edward School opened its doors for the first time in September 1953 to one hundred one pupils in grades one through six. The faculty consisted of three sisters of the Order of St. Francis. Sister M. Charline was the principal and Reverend Vincent Jones was the pastor of the parish.

The school grew rapidly and by 1955 grade seven was added with the addition of grade eight in 1957. Enrollment began to decline and grades seven and eight were eliminated in 1970. column1: 1179430;"ST JOHN LUTHERAN  SCHOOL";"7960 STATE ROUTE 38";"MILFORD CENTER";"OH";43045;"UNION";4402352297;"http://stpaulchuckery.360unite.com/";"sueann.dillahunt@stpaulchuckery.church";"Welcome  to  the  new  school  year  at  St.  Paul
Early  Childhood  Center
.    We  look  forward  to
serving
your  family  and  appreciate  you
sharing your child’s precious preschool time with us.
This handbook contains information that will be important to you and your child.  Please read it
carefully and feel f
ree to contact any staff member with questions.
Mission Statement
St. Paul
Early Childhood Center
will provide stimulus for growth and development of the whole
child in a child
centered Christian environment.
Philosophy
St. Paul
Early Childhood Center
adheres to the philosophy of educating the “whole child” soul
mind
column2: and body. The goal is to provide the children with the opportunity to grow and learn at

column1: their own rate and in their own way.
We believe in the academic/developmental approach of educating
the child. The developmental
approach is based on the assumption that a child’s growth is sequential in nature and an orderly
process involving spiritual
column2: physical
column3: emotional
column4: social
column5: language and cognitive growth

column1: each child is a unique individu
al.
Being developmentally appropriate with a 3
5 year old child involves learning through “play”
and “hands
on activities.” Children are introduced to growth concepts and encouraged to try out
their ideas with emphasis on the process rather than the produc
t. They are given opportunities to
interact with other children and adults in both large and small group settings
column2: as well as on an

column1: individual basis to enhance their communication skills and social growth. Small group
instruction will be planned with speci

fic growth goals in mind";"http://stpaulchuckery.360unite.com/";"https://web.facebook.com/pg/stpaulearlychildhoodcenter/";;"https://unite-production.s3.amazonaws.com/tenants/stpaulchuckery/attachments/140606/PS_Applic._for_Admiss_Form__2018-2019_.pdf";"https://unite-production.s3.amazonaws.com/tenants/stpaulchuckery/attachments/122649/2017-18_PS_student_handbook_-__rev..pdf";;;"x";"x";;;"https://unite-production.s3.amazonaws.com/tenants/stpaulchuckery/pictures/73765/ECC_Logo__4_.jpg";"8:30 a.m.-2:45p.m";"8:30 a.m.-2:45p.m";"8:30 a.m.-2:45p.m";"8:30 a.m.-2:45p.m";"8:30 a.m.-2:45p.m";"Closed";"Closed";

1179442;"ST JOSEPH MONTESSORI";"933 HAMLET ST";"COLUMBUS";"OH";43201;"FRANKLIN";6142918601;"https://www.sjms.net/";"mbrenner@cdeducation.org";"For 50 years
column2: St. Joseph Montessori School has been inspiring students to become innovative thinkers and passionate learners. Our school is a place where children are deeply engaged in the excitement of learning
column3: a process that both challenges and nurtures them and develops self-confidence
column4: competency
column5: imagination
column6: and the desire to lead lives of positive influence. I am excited that you have considered our Catholic Montessori school for your child.

column1: Our Montessori curriculum integrates a philosophy that promotes higher order thinking and abstract reasoning skills for students 3 years old through the 8th Grade. This remarkable program gives our students a deeper understanding of the connection between academics and the outside world. We are a community that understands and values the connection between younger and older students.
Success in school is directly tied to the degree to which children believe that they are capable and independent human beings. If they knew the words
column2: even very young children would declare: “Help me learn to do it for myself!” By allowing children to develop a meaningful degree of independence and self-discipline
column3: Montessori sets a pattern for a lifetime of good work habits and a sense of responsibility. Students are taught to take pride in doing things for themselves carefully and well. column1: 1179456;"ST MARY";"66 E WILLIAM ST";"DELAWARE";"OH";43015;"DELAWARE";7403628961;"http://stmarydelaware.org/";"saintmarychildcare@gmail.com";"St. Mary School has been educating Catholic children in Delaware County since 1860. Uniting the traditions of the Church with current academic practices
column2: our private school provides students in preschool through eighth grade a parochial education at a fraction of the cost of most other private institutions.

column1: Accredited by the State of Ohio and under the direction of the Diocese of Columbus
column2: St. Mary currently enrolls more than 300 students. The student to teacher ratio is 14/1. Our fully licensed staff participates in monthly professional development and works to individualize instruction for their students. St. Mary School welcomes all children to attend and learn in this caring
column3: nurturing
column4: and innovative environment. Students participate in service projects both at school and through the parish.

column1: St. Mary School provides many opportunities for students to practice their faith. Through daily prayer and religion classes
column2: weekly mass
column3: a strong message of discipleship and participation in traditional Catholic sacraments and feasts
column4: St. Mary students live out their faith. The strong impact of these early experiences in Church activities develops a moral guide for students as they face their future. column1: 1179457;"ST MARY";"237 4TH ST";"ELYRIA";"OH";44035;"LORAIN";4403222808;"http://www.stmarycatholicschoolelyria.com/";"mpolingsms@yahoo.com";"St. Mary’s School has been in the business of educating and preparing tomorrow’s leaders since 1859.
St. Mary’s offers families the option of all-day preschool and all-day Kindergarten along with an extended day option.  Our students come from all over Lorain County
column2: and bussing is provided by the Elyria School District
column3: Midview School District and Keystone School District.  We are providing a top notch private school education to children residing in the Elyria
column4: LaGrange
column5: Grafton

column1: As it has since 1859
column2: a strong emphasis is of course placed on a faith centered education. Christian principles are integrated into the curriculum not only in formal study
column3: but also as a way of life.  This is a welcomed change for families seeking an education that continues beyond math and English
column4: and includes an emphasis on Christian morals and values.

column1: In addition to an education that is second to none in the Lorain County area – St. Mary’s School proudly supports our numerous sporting and extra-curricular programs.

Where most schools leave off – St. Mary’s School of Elyria is just beginning. We do not stop at the basic requirement of a public school – which is to assist students in mastering basic educational skills.  St. Mary’s School takes it to the next level as we prepare our students for their future roles.  Not only do we make every effort through our teaching style to enhance the individual student’s self-esteem
column2: but we work to nurture their leadership skills.  Students are taught self-discipline
column3: and encouraged to foster a responsibility for peace and justice.  Our students do not need to be Catholic to attend St. Mary’s School.  They simply need to be open to a Christian education.  Is St. Mary’s tradition of excellence in Christian education the right fit for your child?  Call our office at 440-322-2808 for additional information

column1: 1179470;"ST MARY CATHOLIC SCHOOL";"1630 ASHLAND RD";"MANSFIELD";"OH";44905;"RICHLAND";4195892114;"http://www.mansfieldstmaryschool.org/";"brubaker.christa@mansfieldstmarymail.org";"St. Mary School in Mansfield
column2: Ohio takes great pride in their students and their history in Mansfield and Richland County. The school and parish belong to The Catholic Diocese of Toledo. In 1950 the school was started in Mansfield on Newman Street with an enrollment of 145 students. The present school and parish are now located east of Mansfield on St. Rt. 42. The school was opened on August 5
column3: 1969 with Sister Vivian serving as the first principal. Mass was held in the school cafeteria until the church was built and dedicated on June 20
column4: 1982. Father Bonifas
column5: Pastor

column1: and Father Ceranowski
column2: Associate Pastor presided at the dedication.

column1: Father Nelson Beaver serves as the current Pastor and school superintendent. He is assisted by Father Joseph
column2: Associate Pastor visiting from the Diocese of Tanzania. We maintain an average of 130 students preschool through eight.

column1: St. Mary has a dedicated staff who are all certified through the state of Ohio. The school is accredited by the Ohio Catholic School Accrediting Association. Instruction is offered for grades one through eight
column2: all day kindergarten and preschool. Classes in computers
column3: music
column4: physical education
column5: art
column6: and life skills are part of the curriculum. The school receives students from both Richland and Ashland Counties including the school districts of Ashland
column8: Lexington
column10: Madison

column1: Service to school
column2: parish
column3: and community is an important aspect of our educational goals. Students are involved in mission activities on a local and global level including monthly nursing home visits
column4: canned food drives
column5: Operation Rice Bowl and support to our local Catholic Charities. Students attend and participate in a weekly Friday Mass.

column1: 1179472;"ST MARY OF THE FALLS";"8262 COLUMBIA RD";"OLMSTED FALLS";"OH";44138;"CUYAHOGA";4402354580;"http://www.stmaryofthefallsschool.com/";"Elizabeth.DeVito@stmaryofthefallsschool.com";"In 1849 the first Catholic
column2: John Reynolds arrived in Olmsted Falls.  The first Mass was celebrated in 1854 in a log house  that belonged to the village.  The first pastor of St. Mary of the Falls was named
column3: Fr. Louis Fillieren
column4: in 1856.  The parish school was started in 1873 and closed in 1900 during the financial panic that gripped the nation during that time.

column2: the first church was destroyed by a fire.  In 1949
column3: the parish built the school building with the basement to be used as a church.  The school was staffed by the Sisters of St. Joseph.  In 1958 because of increased enrollment
column4: two portable buildings
column5: former barracks
column6: were were moved 35 miles from Christ the King Parish in East Cleveland to St. Mary of the Falls.  These became classrooms for the primary grades.

column1: Our current all day kindergarten program was initiated in 1987 and in 1991 the first computer lab was built.  In 1997 the construction of the current school building began.  St. Mary of the Falls School celebrated its 60 year anniversary in 2009.
Preschool (Preschool three
column2: four
column3: and PK) was added prior to 2009 where each year since it's beginning
column4: our program has grown and expanded.

column1: Today
column2: our school continues to be strong; educating students  in Preschool through Grade 8 in mind
column3: body
column4: and spirit.";"http://www.stmaryofthefallsschool.com/";"https://web.facebook.com/St-Mary-of-the-Falls-308136249357267/?ref=page_internal";;"http://www.stmaryofthefallsschool.com/admissions/";"http://www.stmaryofthefallsschool.com/academics/handbook.cfm";;;"x";;;;"http://www.stmaryofthefallsschool.com/custom/images/logo1.png";"7:20 a.m.-2:30 p.m";"7:20 a.m.-2:30 p.m";"7:20 a.m.-2:30 p.m";"7:20 a.m.-2:30 p.m";"7:20 a.m.-2:30 p.m";"Closed";"Closed";

1179475;"ST MICHAEL";"3431 SAINT MICHAELS BLVD NW";"CANTON";"OH";44718;"STARK";3304922657;"https://www.smscanton.org/";"stmichaelelem@youngstowndiocese.org";"In 1952
column2: under the leadership of Reverend Ferdinand Hartmann
column3: the first mass of St. Michaels took place on July 6th. The mass was held in the auditorium of Avondale School with 250 in attendance. In order to assist with funding of the parish
column4: clubs were formed by men and women. At this time babysitting clubs were also formed so that men and women could attend the meetings of the various clubs. This cooperative spirit has continued to be a part of the parish today. The parish was able to purchase a rectory in late 1952
column5: and this housed the pastor as well as served as a gathering for weekday masses. The equipment for this was all donated
column6: and the parish began to grow. The goal of the Fr. Hartmann was to make St. Michaels the home of ""friendly people."" Although the church was the main priority
column7: members of St. Michaels were even more eager to provide a Catholic education for for their children. The first campaign dinner for this construction was launched in 1953
column8: and within in 10 days $130
column9: 000 was raised for the cause. The school was officially established on November 23
column11: with the arrival of the four sisters of Notre Dame to help prepare with the opening. The first communion class of 1954 consisted of 22 students
column12: and 6 students graduated that same year. The first outside activities were also created in 1954
column16: as well as San Michel Club for teenagers and a Garden Club for women. The parish has since grown in both size and population
column17: and has recently celebrated it's 60th anniversary in 2012. It has grown to accomodate 2
column18: 300 families with over 900 families in the grade school and the school of religion. column1: 1179477;"ST MICHAEL CONSOLIDATED";"300 MARKET ST";"RIPLEY";"OH";45167;"BROWN";9373924202;"http://stmichaelripley.com/";"kelly.gilkerson@stmichaelripley.org";"St. Michael offers a truly unique educational experience.  We combine the Catholic school experience with a small town
column2: rural values creating a family atmosphere which can only be found at St. Michael.  Our students are taught the faith every day and have the opportunity to participate in Holy Mass every Friday and are able to pray several times a day including participating in activities like stations of the cross
column3: praying the rosary and adoration of the Holy Eucharist.  In addition to the core classes that students would receive at our public school counterparts
column4: St. Michael students have art
column5: music and physical education.  This year we are adding keyboarding and foreign language curriculum as well.

column1: We are the only Catholic school in Brown County and we have children from as far away as North Adams School District and Felicity.  We have buses that run from Georgetown and Ripley. Although we do charge tuition
column2: it is very reasonable and tuition assistance is available through both state-sponsored scholarships and other funding.  St. Michael students are able to participate in the same extra-curricular activities as students from other schools.  Although we are a Catholic school and we do teach our faith
column3: we have many non-Catholic students who enjoy our Christian-based curriculum.  So
column4: if we are the right fit for you
column5: please don’t hesitate to contact us regarding your enrollment at St. Michael School!

column1: As of October 1

1179483;"ST PATRICK";"420 E WATER ST";"TROY";"OH";45373;"MIAMI";9373393705;"http://www.stpattroy.org/";"rsprock@stpattroy.org";"St. Patrick School has a rich and storied history dating back to 1888.  The parish had been serving the growing Catholic members of Troy for more than a quarter of a century when they planned for the construction of a new elementary school just north of the church on Crawford Street. It became a commanding two-story building with grades 6
column3: and 8 on the first floor
column4: and grades 2
column7: and 5 on the second floor.  The top floor was shared with the Sisters of the Precious Blood that taught at the school.  This “red brick school” served the parish well.  The cost to build the school was $2

column1: “St. Patrick Free School”
column2: as it was called
column3: opened with nearly 50 students.  Operating expenses were met through an assessment of $2.40 from each parishioner over the age of 16.  The word “free” was appropriate because there was no tuition to attend the school.

column1: Ground breaking for a new school took place in November of 1952
column2: with the cornerstone being put in place on April 10
column3: 1953.  The new school had 8 of the most modern classrooms
column4: separate playgrounds for boys and girls
column5: and a beautifully equipped kitchen.  This new state of the art building opened to students on September 14

column1: 1179484;"ST PATRICK OF HEATHERDOWNS";"4201 HEATHERDOWNS BLVD";"TOLEDO";"OH";43614;"LUCAS";4193811775;"http://toledostpatsschool.org/";"mary.miller@toledostpats.org";"The first step in establishing St. Patrick’s as a parish was made on June 15
column2: 1955 when Bishop George Rehring purchased an eleven acre plot along Heatherdowns Boulevard from sisters Emma and Louise Kneer.

column1: The parish was officially “born” on June 7
column3: when Fr. James Brogan was appointed associate pastor at Maumee St. Joseph
column4: armed with a list of 615 families who would become his new parish. Legend has it that Fr. Brogan visited each and every one of those households personally.

column1: On September 23
column3: a meeting of the new parish was held at Our Lady of Perpetual Help
column4: and the name “St. Patrick” was chosen upon the Bishop’s recommendation. Fr. Brogan’s middle name
column5: by the way

column1: Before the church was built
column2: the first Masses were held in the auditorium of Heatherdowns School; there were four Masses each Sunday
column3: with Fr. William Seelaus
column4: an Oblate from St. Francis deSales High School assisting Fr. Brogan.

column1: The first Sunday collection at St. Pat’s totaled $4
Ground was broken for the church and school on St. Patrick’s Day – March 17
column2: 1957. A St. Patrick’s Day party followed – in a tradition that was kept for 37 years.

column1: The first Mass celebrated on St. Pat’s property was in November of 1957
column2: in the basement of the new building.

column1: The first Mass celebrated in the church building was Midnight Mass on Christmas Eve 1957.
In the winter of 1957
column2: at the direction of the Bishop
column3: a house was purchased on what is now Green Valley to serve as a temporary rectory. Fourteen years later
column4: a house down the road was built by parishioner Ken Mossing to serve as the convent. Beginning in 1990 events came full circle and the convent house now serves as the rectory.

column1: In September of 1958
column2: 527 students started their school year at St. Patrick’s School in the West wing
column3: now known as Seton Hall. As St. Pat’s rapidly grew
column4: in 1960 the East Wing – what is now known as Neumann Hall – was added
column5: complete with 13 more classrooms.

column2: the new rectory
column3: now called the Crites Community Center
column4: was completed
column5: and served as home to three pastors
column6: 22 other priests (including the late Bishop James Hoffman)
column8: three youth directors
column9: and numerous others in its 27 years as a residence. The Crites Center was named after Peg and Chuck Crites
column10: who were longtime volunteer workers during the years of Fr. Brogan and Fr. Wilhelm.";"http://toledostpatsschool.org/";"https://web.facebook.com/StPatrickOfHeatherdowns/?_rdc=1&_rdr";;"toledostpatsschool.org/registration";"https://cld.bz/fjYsKTo";;;;"x";;;"https://s3.amazonaws.com/media.cloversites.com/24/24cd79d3-d14b-4e86-95f9-83e447bb7a43/site-images/4344e28a-9285-4faf-b722-b72f658d8bbc.png";"8:45a.m.-3:00 p.m";"8:45a.m.-3:00 p.m";"8:45a.m.-3:00 p.m";"8:45a.m.-3:00 p.m";"8:45a.m.-3:00 p.m";"Closed";"Closed";

column2: we believe our Catholic School is not only a school

column1: 1179506;"ST SEBASTIAN";"352 ELMDALE AVE";"AKRON";"OH";44320;"SUMMIT";3308369107;"http://www.stsebastian.org/";"rohra@stsebastian.org";"For nearly 90 years
column2: St. Sebastian Parish School has provided a high-quality
column3: catholic education to students in West Akron. While continuing our long tradition of excellent education in core subjects taught in a faith-based environment
column4: St. Sebastian also stays on the forefront of educational technology and teaching methods. This year we celebrated the opening of our Innovation Lab
column5: a maker-space classroom that houses an amazing array of educational materials and offers a large

column1: Our school’s impressive technology resources include a 1:1 technology program for grades 6-8
column2: more than 250 laptops and iPads for use by younger grades
column3: SMARTboards in every classroom
column4: a state-of-the-art Science Lab
column5: and a brand new Technology Learning Lab featuring new computers and a 3D printer. St. Sebastian recently earned designation as a STEM (science
column7: engineering and math) school by the Ohio Department of Education in recognition of our comprehensive curriculum that integrates STEM practices such as problem-based learning
column8: critical thinking
column9: and hands-on activities on all grade levels.

column1: As a Catholic school dedicated to developing the whole student
column2: St. Sebastian embraces STREAM education
column3: which adds religion as a core component to the STEM approach. In addition to daily religion classes and weekly Mass
column4: students participate in many service projects and our curriculum emphasizes service learning
column5: such as harvesting produce from the school garden to donate to the Good Samaritan Hunger Center.

column1: Our school’s mission statement is “St. Sebastian School is dedicated to Christ and committed to excellence in education. We honor the Catholic traditions of the past
column2: work to develop our talents today
column3: and prepare for Christian service in the future.” I invite all who are interested in our school to come visit
column4: we’d be happy to show you how our students and faculty live out the mission of the school every day!

column1: Mr. Anthony Rohr – Principal

column1: 1179513;"ST VERONICA";"4475 MOUNT CARMEL TOBASCO RD";"CINCINNATI";"OH";45244;"HAMILTON";5135280442;"https://www.stveronica.org/";"sharon.bresler@stveronica.org";"
St. Veronica School has experienced great growth over the past several years and today we are “home” to 443 students. Our school has excellent academic programs
column2: outstanding professional teachers
column3: and a Christian-disciplined atmosphere where all children have the opportunity to excel. The school family centers on our love for Christ and therefore our love for each other. We are dedicated to excellence and developing positive character in all of our students.

column1: Our experienced staff includes 28 lay teachers and one Franciscan Sister. We have the benefit of a full-time music teacher
column2: PE teacher
column3: Art teacher
column4: Computer teacher
column5: Spanish teacher
column8: intervention specialist
column10: school counselor
column13: and classroom aides.  Our student-to-teacher ratio is 21 to 1.

column1: St. Veronica School has placed strong emphasis on providing quality educational opportunities for all students. We have a fully-operational science lab for 6th
column2: 7th
column3: and 8th grade students. The media center affords 30 computer stations to the students and staff who have access to the Internet and internal e-mail. There are smart boards and additional computers in our classrooms and three wireless laptop carts. The entire school and parish are wired for Internet connectivity since we see technology as a useful tool for all.

column1: We invite you to explore our school and personally witness why St. Veronica is the best Catholic school on the East Side!

1179553;"STS PHILIP AND JAMES";"532 HIGH ST NW";"CANAL FULTON";"OH";44614;"STARK";3308542823;"https://www.saintsphilipandjames.org/";"sspandjelem@youngstowndiocese.org";"The school’s history goes back over 140 years. Saints Philip and James School (SPJ) opened in 1875 with 12 boys and 16 girls and one lay teacher. Records show the old school was torn down and a new school was built in 1935. Another section was added in 1967 and the second floor was built in 1979.The Sisters of Notre Dame staffed the school from 1883 to 1885 and again from 1941 to 1975. column1: 1179564;"SUNRISE ACADEMY";"5657 SCIOTO DARBY RD";"HILLIARD";"OH";43026;"FRANKLIN";6145270465;"https://www.sunriseacademy.net/";"msalti@sunriseacademy.net";"Sunrise Academy was inaugurated as the first full-time chartered Islamic school in central Ohio in 1996 under the Islamic Society of Greater Columbus (ISGC) umbrella. column2: Ohio
column3: a suburb of Columbus. Sunrise Academy provides academic programs for students in Pre-K through 8th grade.

column1: Sunrise Academy currently has over 400 students from over thirty different countries enrolled for the current academic school year. We believe our diversity is one of our greatest strengths.

Our highly qualified and talented staff comes from a variety of rich cultural backgrounds. Their commitment to the Sunrise Academy mission gives them the role of active agents in the process of academic excellence.
